posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked:
Hello CD Experts,

Our team is looking into purchasing a laser cutter for next season. After searching through recent posts from Chief Delphi, we haven’t found anything newer than pre-2020. Here’s what we’re seeking:

1. A laser cutter rated 120+ Watts
2. With a 4' x 4' cutting bed capacity
3. Priced under $7k (preferably under $5k if feasible)

Do you have a laser cutter you highly recommend?  

TIA

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: A 60W machine can perform tasks typically handled by a 120W machine in FIRST Robotics Competition. I focus more on the machine's overall quality than its wattage. A relevant saying: "What is cheap, is expensive."

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: There are several out there but Swyft has one it's not the size you might expect it's designed for frc teams rapid prototyping quick iterations on the fly. The product is a co2 laser cutter which offers significant advantages during the build season. It allows for rapid prototyping cutting and shaping components quickly while eliminating the need for outsourcing parts or waiting for deliveries. The price is usd 349999 making it an affordable yet powerful tool for competition-level projects.

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked: Heavily important to note, cheaper options often fail or are difficult to use. I fully agree with that observation. I must stick to budget guidelines set by my school district. Any expenses exceeding \$5k require three bids. The power rating was suggested by a local engineer.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The wattage was recommended by a local engineer. Ask him what his opinion on a 60W laser would be, given a workflow mostly involving plywood and delrin (these are, I think, consensus best-materials for FIRST Robotics Competition laser cutting). I think you might get a better quality machine at your price point at that power level. I could be wrong, though!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked: I'm confused about their recommendation regarding the 100w+ product. The primary materials intended for use include plywood up to 1-inch thickness, polycarb in both 1/8-inch and 1/4-inch thicknesses, and aluminum for engraving purposes.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Polycarb - both 1/8" and 1/4" thickness. Warning: Results will be acceptable at best, and sloppy/awful at worst. Be really sure you have your ventilation set up if you're cutting polycarb; the fumes are particularly nasty/corrosive. 1/4” is going to be particularly troublesome.

Delrin is a really good choice because it’s really hard to screw up a cut – it tends to vaporize cleanly at the cut interface instead of melting.

Acrylic cuts the nicest of all the plastics, but is too brittle to be useful except for aesthetics.

Always favor low power and multiple passes!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked: You have no idea how much I appreciate the advice! I’m not the engineering mastermind, just the IT teacher who has learned more about engineering than I ever dreamed and all of it from getting involved with FIRST Robotics Competition 18 years ago. Anything else you might recommend that we watch out for? We want to use the laser cutter for quick prototyping with plywood and bumper frames. For our builds, the polycarb is used mainly for protecting components and very occasionally for various structural pieces—for instance, this year we manufactured our coral intake using both 1/8 and 1/4 polycarb, last year our under the bumper and over the frame intake had polycarb side plates. My thought was that the laser cutter might be a better option than our CNC machine for those cuts and it would free up the CNC for aluminum work.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Be prepared to service the thing and replace the lenses/mirrors on a scheduled basis. lightning fast part turnover on a laser means rapid iteration. waste time on a mill/router until you know the dimensions once you have a laser so don’t. lasers are a great first CNC machine experience for students because there’s no workholding and it’s relatively easy to avoid machine damage. use that in your training sequence. let your students make art on the laser during off times engraving is cool and helps practice machine settings.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: I own two lasers. One is a CO2 laser, and the other is a 30w fiber laser. Engraving aluminum hasn't worked well for me, but marking it with spray paint works much better.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Now...this is IF you spend a lot of time at 100%. Addendum: don’t. As I mentioned above, the best strategy for both cut quality and tool longevity is to run at lower duty cycles for multiple passes. This takes longer, but the laser is already such a fast machine that the difference doesn’t matter much. Shoutout to the University of Maryland for teaching me these best practices as a research intern :wink:.

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked: We planned to obtain some SRPP this season, but unfortunately, we’ve already exhausted our WC purchase order. This necessitates adjusting certain figures to reallocate more funds toward West Coast Products next year.

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked:
SRPP will be a key component moving forward.  
We have access to a 155W Boss LS-3655 laser cutter that efficiently processes SRPP. After switching to a 2.5-inch lens setup, the REV cut settings are spot-on.  

This is a sizable machine capable of handling 23x47-inch sheets. Fully equipped in 2024 cost around $18k. Highly recommended.

link_counts.title: LS-3655 CO2 Laser Cutter and Engraver - Boss Laser – BossLaser

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked: We own a 100w 2*3 ThunderLaser and still highly recommend them. When considering purchasing again, we'd aim for the highest possible wattage and area within our budget, such as a 150W 3*4 model. The increased wattage allows for processing thicker materials and speeds up cutting times, while the larger footprint enables tasks like full-size belly pans, robot covers, and larger sponsor panels. OMtech appears to offer good value and has received positive reviews. However, xTool machines are becoming popular, though metal cutting capabilities aren't yet fully established, and we await more detailed information before making a recommendation.

posts.name: Jackie Gerstein
posts.cooked:
I've got an Aeon Mira 9 and a 30W fiber galvo laser. I love both machines, but the Mira 9 is well out of your budget and the galvo isn't going to do what you need.

We are looking for:

- 120+ Watt
- 4’ x 4’ bed
- <$7k ($<5k would be amazing but probably not reasonable)

I’m not aware of anything that meets all these requirements. Which of your criteria are non-negotiable, and what can you be flexible on?

Also, have you budgeted for ventilation? If you aren’t able to vent the laser outside, you’ll need to budget for a fume extractor and regular filter replacements, which will eat into your budget pretty significantly.

The main materials we want to use it for are:

- Plywood - up to 1" thickness
- Polycarb - both 1/8" and 1/4" thickness
- Aluminum - engraving

I love laser cutters, but between the size and the materials, this is really starting to sound more like a CNC router than a laser cutter to me.

Plywood: Plywood cuts very well on a laser, but 1" is really going to be pushing it. You can make it work on a high-power CO2 laser with a long focal-length lens, but you’ll need to be patient. Above 3/4" or so, I’d be really considering whether a CNC router is a better choice.

Polycarbonate: Absolutely awful on a laser. You can cut it, but as mentioned, you’ll get nasty fumes and a low-quality cut. It’s slow too. Much better suited to a CNC router.

Aluminum: You can use a CO2 laser for marking, but you won’t be able to engrave.

Laser cutter vs CNC router: We want to use the laser cutter for quick prototyping with plywood and bumper frames. My thought was that the laser cutter might be a better option than our current CNC for those cuts and it would free up the CNC for aluminum.

This works well because it allows us to use both the laser and the CNC effectively. We did a lot of early prototypes in cardboard and plywood, saving both the more expensive materials and time on the CNC router for more thoroughly developed parts. Prototyping on the laser was fast enough that my students could iterate through several versions in a 3-hour meeting.

With that said, maybe considering whether a 4’x4’ 120W laser is necessary. Our team used a 24"x18" 60W (RF tube) laser, and it wasn’t a major limitation.

Most lasers in your price range are glass tube lasers, requiring water cooling. Budget for a chiller if it doesn’t come with your machine. RF tube lasers are more expensive but last longer, don’t need cooling, and offer similar power to glass tube lasers.

Suggestions:

- Thunder Laser: Balance of price and quality, good support.
- Omtech: More budget-friendly but potentially frustrating.
- Hao-Tian Fiber Lasers: Affordable options available.

If you go down to a 2028 100W model, you can stay under your preferred budget.
